text: you've been ripped off and you want to
pay back there are plenty of movies that
satisfy this craving but there aren't
many characters that embody vengeance as
forcefully as purely as nasty as Lee
Marvin's Walker John Boorman's Walker's
angry because the guy he thought he was
his best friend
Mallory's played by John Vernon took
Walker's money $93,000 and his wife and
shot Walker and left him to die in an
abandoned cell in Alcatraz somehow
Walker survives and he goes to Los
Angeles to hunt down his wife and his ex
best friend he finds that things are a
little more complicated than he thought
instead of just two treacherous people
he's faced with a shadowy network of
businessmen called the organization and
the organization can't seem to give them
what he wants no matter how forcefully
he asks there's a sleazy car dealer and
unto his business executive and a fat
man with a briefcase played by Carroll
O'Connor we deal in minions we never see
cash there's also a mysterious
mastermind played by Keenan Wynn who
guides Walker on his quest for vengeance
Walker's only real Ally is his
sister-in-law played with steely
seductiveness by Angie Dickinson and she
manages to find Walker's softer side
the director John Boorman fractures
chronology plays with the sound design
and uses dramatic widescreen
compositions to create a Los Angeles
seething with violence paranoia and
intense melancholy but what is point
blank really about on the face of it
it's a simple straightforward story of
revenge or maybe frustrated within but
really it's an allegory about the fate
of the individual in a world dominated
by corporate power every step of the way
Walker believes he's acting in his own
self-interest but come on he's a pawn
